Our results show that deep learning models, specifically convolutional neural networks, outperform traditional image segmentation methods. However, we also identify several areas of improvement in the performance of these models, and highlight the importance of data augmentation and hyperparameter tuning in achieving state-of-the-art results. Overall, our benchmark provides a valuable resource for researchers and practitioners working in the field of food image segmentation.

We introduce a family of Nikishin systems with periodic recurrence coefficients, which generalize the classical periodic Nikishin system. We study the asymptotic behavior of these systems for large values of $N.$ We obtain that the number of states in the Markov partition of the system divided by $N$ converges to a well-defined limit as $N\rightarrow\infty.$ The limits we obtain satisfy the so-called Weiss condition, which ensures the convergence of the corresponding entropy functional. We also show that the Markov partition is asymptotically optimal. Our results show that in the periodic case the recurrence coefficients form an ergodic structure on the state space of the system, and we describe this structure in terms of the Weiss condition. Our proofs use a combination of the classical Nikishin method and techniques from Markov partitions.

The field of computer vision has seen a significant increase in interest and development over recent years, with deep learning techniques playing an integral role. One such technique is the use of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to segment surfaces in 3D space. However, traditional CNN architectures have limitations when it comes to handling complex surface geometries and hierarchical structures. In this study, we propose a novel approach that utilizes contour tree hierarchy to improve the performance of deep neural network-based 3D surface segmentation. Our method involves first constructing a contour tree representation of the input surface, which captures its topological structure at multiple scales. We then apply a series of convolutional layers to extract features from each level of the contour tree, followed by a fully connected layer to classify the segments. Experimental results show that our proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency, particularly for surfaces with intricate shapes and hierarchical structures. Overall, our work demonstrates the potential of using contour tree hierarchy as a powerful tool for improving the performance of deep neural network-based 3D surface segmentation tasks.

This paper presents a theoretical analysis of the time reversal of light by linear dispersive filtering near atomic resonance. The authors demonstrate that by using a linear dispersive filter, it is possible to reverse the direction of time flow in a small region around an atomic resonance. The paper provides a detailed mathematical model of the process and shows that it is possible to achieve a high degree of time reversal with a relatively simple experimental setup. The results of this study have important implications for the development of new technologies in the field of quantum mechanics and could lead to new insights into the fundamental nature of time.

This academic paper presents an information-theoretic derivation of min-cut based clustering. The main result of the paper is a formal connection between the concept of information gain and the min-cut cutset selection criterion used in min-cut clustering algorithms. The authors prove a theorem that provides a rigorous mathematical foundation for the use of min-cut based clustering in terms of information gain, which demonstrates the utility of this approach in a variety of applications. The paper also explores potential avenues for future research, including the generalization of the results to more complex clustering problems and the development of new algorithms based on information theoretical principles.

QANet is a novel approach to quality assurance in image segmentation. It utilizes a network architecture that incorporates multiple levels of feedback and validation, allowing it to detect errors and improve accuracy in real-time. The system uses a combination of supervised and unsupervised learning techniques to train its models, ensuring that they are able to handle a wide range of input data. Additionally, QANet includes features such as automatic error detection and correction, which can help reduce the time and resources required for manual quality control. Overall, this research presents a significant advancement in the field of image segmentation, providing a reliable and efficient method for ensuring high-quality results.

In this paper, we study conformal parameterizations of slices of flat Kasner spacetimes. We first define a suitable metric on these spacetimes and then derive relevant equations that govern their expansion dynamics using the Newman-Janis approach to wormholes. We show how these solutions can be classified into four distinct classes based on the behavior of their singularities in both spatial dimensions. Our analysis provides insights into the possible nature of future singularity landscapes that may arise from initial conditions involving such spacetime geometries.

DOI: 10.485617

WAYLA (Wearable Augmented Reality Yielding Liveness and Authenticity) is a novel approach to generative computer vision that harnesses eye movements as input and produces photographic images in real-time. The aim of this study was to explore whether it is possible to generate compelling photographs using only 30 seconds or less worth of eye movement captured from an individual wearing a wearable device equipped with a camera, microphone, and accelerometer.

We conducted experiments with both nonprofessional subjects and professional photographers, collecting data about their eye movements during various scenes and post-image processing techniques. Our findings indicate that it is indeed possible to generate high-quality images with minimal time spent capturing eye movement data. Furthermore, we found that the resulting images possess a sense of authenticity due to subtle differences in perspective and movement patterns that are present in every person's visual experience.

The use of advanced machine learning models and real-time rendering algorithms enables us to create vivid imagery in the blink of an eye. This opens up new possibilities in areas such as personalized fashion advertising and entertainment, where dynamic imagery can be synchronized with user interactions in real-time. Future work will focus on further improving the quality and variety of generated imagery by incorporating additional sensors and feedback mechanisms into our system.

Sleep staging is a critical task in the field of sleep research, which involves identifying different stages of sleep based on electroencephalogram (EEG) signals. Traditional methods for sleep staging rely on manual labeling of EEG data, which is time-consuming and prone to errors. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to sleep staging using a fully convolutional network (FCN) called U-Time. U-Time is designed to segment EEG signals into non-overlapping time windows, and then classify each window into one of the five sleep stages. We evaluate U-Time on a publicly available dataset of EEG recordings, and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art methods for sleep staging. Specifically, U-Time achieves an accuracy of 95.5% on the validation set, compared to 93.8% for the best previous method. Our results demonstrate the potential of deep learning techniques for automating the task of sleep staging, and pave the way for future research in this area.

The paper presents a novel approach to automated image segmentation using deep active contour models. The proposed method is end-to-end trainable, allowing for the direct segmentation of aerial imagery without the need for manual labeling. The model is designed to delineate buildings in aerial imagery, and is trained on a large dataset of labeled images. The results show that the proposed method is highly accurate and outperforms state-of-the-art methods for building segmentation in aerial imagery.

This paper presents a novel deep learning approach to earth image segmentation using imperfect polyline labels with annotation errors. The proposed method utilizes a combination of convolutional neural networks (CNN) and graph-based algorithms to improve the accuracy of segmentation results in cases where labeling is not perfect or contains errors. The CNN extracts features from input images, while the graph-based algorithm uses these features to generate accurate segmentation masks. The model is trained on a large dataset of labeled earth images, which includes both correct and incorrect labeling. Results show that the proposed method outperforms traditional methods by achieving higher accuracy rates even when dealing with noisy data.

The field of image segmentation has seen significant advancements in recent years, with deep learning techniques such as convolutional neural networks (CNNs) achieving state-of-the-art performance. However, these methods often struggle to accurately capture complex object boundaries and suffer from overfitting. In this paper, we propose a novel approach called BoundarySqueeze that addresses these challenges by treating image segmentation as boundary squeezing. Our method involves first identifying the most important pixels along each edge of objects in an image, and then iteratively refining their positions until they form tight, accurate boundaries. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark datasets, including the COCO dataset, where our model achieves competitive results with significantly fewer parameters than traditional CNN architectures.

The proposed real-time predictive maintenance platform utilizes a combination of sensors, machine learning algorithms and 3D printing technology to provide businesses with an efficient and cost-effective solution for maintaining their vehicles. This system continuously monitors vehicle performance data in real-time, analyzes it using advanced machine learning techniques, and generates predictive models that can forecast potential issues before they occur. These predictions are then used to schedule preventative maintenance activities, reducing downtime and minimizing repair costs. Additionally, the platform includes a 3D printer module that allows for on-demand production of replacement parts, further streamlining the maintenance process. The proposed system has been tested on a fleet of business vehicles and shown to be highly effective at improving overall vehicle reliability and reducing maintenance expenses.

The abstract of the academic paper titled "RA-UNet: A Hybrid Deep Attention-Aware Network to Extract Liver and Tumor in CT Scans" is as follows:

We present a novel approach called RA-UNet, which is designed specifically to detect and segment organs such as liver and tumors from CT images using an end-to-end learning process. Our model leverages a multi-level fusion mechanism that integrates multiple encoder-decoder architectures with different contextual levels into one single network, resulting in enhanced spatial information processing capacity while maintaining its computational efficiency.

Moreover, we propose implementing spatial awareness via self-attention mechanisms to enable more selective feature extraction during processing CT scans with complex structures or overlapping regions between the target organ(s) and other anatomical elements. In order to further improve performance over existing approaches, our spatial self-attention module also employs multi-level fusion to combine low- and high-level features of interest simultaneously.

The effectiveness of RA-UNet was evaluated on a dataset consisting of 176 CT scans, where both inter-rater reliability and validation performances demonstrated significant improvements compared to conventional deep neural networks without spatial attention mechanisms. Our novel method offers promising potential contributions towards accurate automated detection for a variety of medical imaging applications, including cancer diagnoses, as well as improving overall patient outcomes and reducing diagnostic errors.

In this paper, we present a novel approach to learning object segmentation from misaligned and partial labels. Our method leverages a combination of deep learning and graph-based techniques to improve the performance of segmentation models on noisy and incomplete label data. We propose a graph-based representation of the input image and label data, which allows us to incorporate prior knowledge about the spatial relationships between objects in the image. We also introduce a novel loss function that encourages the model to learn more robust and accurate segmentation results, even when the input labels are misaligned or partial. Our experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark datasets, and show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art segmentation models on noisy and incomplete label data.

In this paper, we present a novel method to study the ultra-directional super-scattering of homogenous spherical particles with radial anisotropy, which is a type of scattering that occurs when the scattering particles have a non-uniform property or shape. We use the finite element method to simulate the scattering and extract the super-scattering coefficients. We also derive an analytical expression for the super-scattering coefficient and study its behavior for different ratios of the particle size to the wavelength. We show that the super-scattering coefficient is maximum at the mid-gap frequency, which is the frequency at which the particles' effective permittivity becomes equal to the medium's permittivity, and it decreases for frequencies above and below this frequency. We also show that the super-scattering coefficient depends on the particle shape, size, and anisotropy. Our results provide insight into the nature of ultra-directional super-scattering, which has important applications in photonics, optoelectronics, and nanotechnology.

The paper "Tiling Vertices and the Spacing Distribution of their Radial Projection" presents a novel approach to analyze the spatial distribution of vertices in a tiled surface. The proposed method involves projecting the vertices onto a plane and measuring the distance between adjacent vertices. The paper shows that the spacing distribution of the projected vertices follows a power-law, which is a common feature of many natural and artificial systems. The authors also demonstrate that the exponent of the power-law depends on the tiling pattern and the geometry of the surface. The results of this study have implications for understanding the behavior of tiled surfaces and for developing algorithms for image processing and computer graphics.

The Morse boundary is a fundamental concept in topology that describes the structure of spaces with curvature. In this paper, we study the Morse boundaries of proper geodesic metric spaces. We first introduce some basic definitions and results related to Morse theory on geodesic metric spaces. Then, we prove several important properties about the Morse boundary of such spaces, including its connectedness, compactness, and continuity. Finally, we discuss some applications of our results to various areas of mathematics, including differential geometry, dynamical systems, and stochastic processes.

Overall, this paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the Morse boundary of proper geodesic metric spaces, shedding light on their geometric and analytical properties. Our work has significant implications for understanding the behavior of complex systems and phenomena that arise from non-Euclidean geometry.

Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy (EELS) is a powerful technique used to study the electronic structure and composition of materials at atomic resolution. However, processing large amounts of data generated by EELS experiments can be challenging due to the complexity of the spectra and the need for accurate analysis. In this paper, we present an approach for data processing of high-resolution EELS images that enables the extraction of detailed information about the electronic structure and bonding in materials. Our method involves the use of machine learning algorithms to automatically identify and classify different types of atoms based on their characteristic energy loss signals. We also introduce a novel algorithm for reconstructing three-dimensional electron density maps from two-dimensional EELS images, which allows us to visualize the distribution of electrons within individual atoms and molecules. Finally, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach using several examples of complex materials, including metals, semiconductors, and insulators. Overall, our work represents a significant advancement in the field of EELS data processing, enabling researchers to extract more detailed and precise information about the electronic structure and bonding of materials at atomic resolution.

In this study, we propose a novel method to estimate cross-validatory predictive p-values using integrated importance sampling (IIS) for disease mapping models. Our approach is based on Bayesian inference and takes into account both model uncertainty and spatial correlation between observations. We demonstrate our method through simulations and an application to real data from the UK Biobank study. Our results show that IIS improves the accuracy of predictive p-values compared to standard methods, particularly when there are complex relationships among variables or when sample sizes are small. Overall, our findings provide important insights into the limitations of existing approaches to disease mapping and highlight the potential benefits of incorporating more sophisticated statistical techniques into these analyses.

Mammogram edge detection is a critical task for breast cancer diagnosis. This study presents a hybrid method for mammogram edge detection using soft computing techniques. The hybrid method combines multiple soft computing methods, including fuzzy logic, neural networks, and support vector machines, to improve the accuracy and robustness of edge detection. The method first applies a fuzzy logic-based technique to preprocess the image data, followed by a neural network-based technique for feature extraction. Finally, a support vector machine-based technique is used to classify the edges. The proposed method was tested on a dataset of mammogram images and achieved superior performance compared to existing methods. The results show that the hybrid method can effectively detect mammogram edges and improve the accuracy of breast cancer diagnosis.

Introduction:

Neuron segmentation is a fundamental task in electron microscopy (EM) image analysis, which is critical for accurately identifying and quantifying neuronal structures within three-dimensional images of the brain. Traditional methods for neuron segmentation rely heavily on user input and manual interaction. Therefore, there is a growing need for automatic methods that can accurately segment neurons automatically with minimal human intervention.

One approach for automatic neuron segmentation is to use deep learning algorithms. However, the training of deep learning models can be computationally demanding and requires a large amount of annotated datasets. In this paper, we propose a novel method for learning metric graphs to segment neurons from EM images. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method by training a graph convolutional network (GCN) on a dataset of EM images of Cerebellar Purkinje cells. Our results show that our method can accurately segment neuron structures without the need for user input or extensive manual labeling of the dataset. Our work paves the way for the development of efficient and accurate methods for neuron segmentation in EM images of the brain.

The paper discusses the use of path integral methods to study the Lorentzian spinfoam model, a quantum gravity theory. The authors investigate the asymptotics of the model and their relationship to simplicial geometries. They use the renormalization group to analyze the model's behavior and find that it exhibits a phase transition between a "tangible" and a "ghostly" phase. The authors also study the contribution of triangles to simplicial geometries and show that their contribution to the path integral is exponentially suppressed for large angles between the legs. Overall, the paper provides new insights into the behavior of the Lorentzian spinfoam model and its relationship to simplicial geometries.

The study aims to optimize the measurement of relativistic distortions in large-scale structure. Relativistic distortions are caused by the gravitational effects of massive objects and can be used as a probe of dark matter distribution. However, measuring these distortions is challenging due to their small amplitude and the presence of noise in observational data. In this work, we develop a new method that uses Bayesian inference to estimate the power spectrum of density perturbations from weak lensing surveys. We show that our method outperforms previous methods in terms of accuracy and robustness, even when dealing with noisy data. Our results demonstrate the potential of using weak lensing surveys to accurately measure relativistic distortions and provide insights into the nature of dark matter.

The Milnor number is a topological invariant that quantifies the number of holes in the singularity of a hypersurface in a smooth projective variety. In arbitrary characteristic, the definition of the Milnor number of a hypersurface singularity must be modified. In this paper, we study the Milnor number of a hypersurface singularity in arbitrary characteristic, and prove several important properties of this invariant. We also study its relation to other topological invariants, such as the homotopy groups, the persistence homology, and the persistent homology of the singular locus. Our results provide a framework for studying the holomorphic singularities of hypersurfaces in arbitrary characteristic, and can be applied to a wide variety of problems in algebraic geometry, commutative algebra, and other areas of mathematics.

Active latitude oscillations observed on the sun refer to periodic fluctuations in solar activity that occur at specific longitudes on the sun's surface. These oscillations are characterized by a rise and fall of solar radiation intensity, which can have significant impacts on space weather and climate patterns on Earth. In this study, we present an analysis of active latitude oscillation data collected over several years using satellite-based observations. Our findings reveal that these oscillations are not only present but also exhibit distinct patterns and characteristics across different wavelengths of solar radiation. We discuss possible mechanisms behind these variations and their potential implications for future research and modeling efforts aimed at predicting solar activity and its effects on our planet. Overall, this work contributes valuable insights into the complex dynamics of the sun and highlights the importance of continued monitoring and study of solar activity for understanding and mitigating its impact on Earth's environment.

The proposed paper introduces TernausNet, a U-Net architecture that incorporates a pre-trained VGG11 encoder to achieve state-of-the-art performance in image segmentation tasks. The VGG11 encoder is trained on ImageNet and fine-tuned for specific image segmentation tasks, enabling the network to learn a more robust representation of image features. The U-Net architecture provides an efficient and effective framework for the output processing, and the TernausNet model achieves faster convergence and better accuracy than previous techniques. The paper demonstrates the effectiveness of TernausNet on various image segmentation tasks and presents improvements in training times and accuracy, making it a valuable contribution to the field of image segmentation research.

Stable planar mesoscopic photonic crystals are a promising technology in various applications, from telecommunications to quantum computing. These structures enable light manipulation at micro and nanoscales, providing effective control of propagation modes, energy levels, and polarization states. In this paper, we discuss recent advances in stable planar mesoscopic photonic crystal fabrication using metal-organic framework techniques. We present an overview of the different types of materials used, including metal oxides, semiconductors, and dielectric matrices. We then discuss experimental methods to achieve high precision, such as extreme ultraviolet lithography and nanofabrication processes. Additionally, we highlight theoretical developments that enable precise analysis of the mechanical stability of these systems under varying conditions. Finally, we review the latest research on stable planar mesoscopic photonic crystals, with emphasis on their potential applications in areas such as sensing, imaging, and energy conversion. Overall, this paper provides a comprehensive review of stable planar mesoscopic photonic crystal fabrication and its various applications.

The unification of relativistic and quantum mechanics is a long-standing goal in theoretical physics. In this paper, we propose a new approach to unifying these two fundamental theories by introducing the concept of elementary cycles theory. This theory suggests that all particles can be described as cyclic entities with different frequencies and amplitudes. We show how this idea leads to a consistent framework for understanding both special and general relativity, as well as quantum mechanics. Our work provides a novel perspective on the nature of matter and energy, and offers new insights into the relationship between space and time.

Title: Unsupervised Learning of Foreground Object Detection

Abstract: In this research, we present an approach to unsupervised learning of foreground object detection. This problem is formulated as a clustering task where the goal is to cluster pixels together based on their probability of belonging to objects in images. We address challenges such as dealing with noise and varying object sizes by introducing novel techniques that improve the quality of results through iterative refinement processes. Our experimental evaluation demonstrates significant improvements over other state-of-the-art methods, achieving competitive performance even without labeled training data. Thus our method provides a more cost-effective solution towards real world applications, opening up new possibilities in industries like surveillance and medical imaging.

DeepSaliency is a novel multi-task deep neural network model designed for salient object detection. The model is trained on multiple tasks simultaneously, including object detection, semantic segmentation, and saliency prediction. The model uses a combination of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to learn the spatial and temporal relationships between objects and their saliency. The model is trained on a large dataset of images and achieves state-of-the-art performance on salient object detection tasks. The paper presents the architecture of the DeepSaliency model, the training algorithm, and experimental results demonstrating the effectiveness of the model. The paper also discusses the potential applications of the model in areas such as computer vision, robotics, and autonomous systems.

This research presents a novel approach to segmentation that is capable of handling multiple acceptable annotations. The study focuses specifically on myocardial segmentation in contrast echocardiography images, where multiple different methods can be used to accurately identify and define the boundaries of the tissue. By analyzing cases with varying levels of complexity and challenging image characteristics, this method was able to improve overall accuracy over previous approaches while also reducing variability among readers. This work has important implications for clinical practice as it expands our understanding of how best to annotate medical imaging data, making it more accessible and useful for diagnosis and treatment planning.

The consistency of matter models with asymptotically safe quantum gravity is a subject of ongoing research in theoretical physics and cosmology. This paper aims to explore the relationship between matter models and the underlying structure of the universe, specifically focusing on quantum gravity. The authors argue that matter models should be consistent with the predictions of quantum gravity in order to better understand the behavior of matter and energy at the most fundamental level. They propose a framework for testing the consistency of matter models with astrophysical observations and numerical simulations, and discuss potential consequences for our understanding of cosmic structure and evolution. Overall, this paper provides a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on the nature of matter and its relationship to quantum gravity.

The study of the non-compressible solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations presents a unique opportunity to derive the properties of spacetime. These equations are a vital tool in understanding fluid dynamics and the behavior of fluids under different conditions. By analyzing the non-compressible solutions, we can gain insight into the structure and behavior of spacetime in the context of fluid dynamics. This allows us to explore the relationships between the properties of spacetime and those of fluids and may lead to new insights into the nature of our universe. The study of non-compressible solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations has important implications for fields such as astrophysics, cosmology, and high-energy physics.

The Lin-Ni-Takagi (LNT) problem is a well-known open question in mathematical physics that concerns the existence of interior bubbles in three-dimensional fluids. In this study, we investigate the LNT problem using interior bubbling solutions, which are solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations with an additional source term that models the formation and growth of bubbles. We show that there exist interior bubbling solutions to the LNT problem under certain conditions on the initial data and parameters. Our results provide new insights into the behavior of fluid systems with bubble formation and have important implications for understanding phase transitions and other physical phenomena involving bubbles.

This paper presents a new approach to describing the dynamics of gravitational phenomena, based on the concept of shape space. By considering objects as points in shape space and using geometric methods to analyze their properties, we are able to describe the evolution of shapes under the influence of gravity fields. We apply this framework to various problems such as planetary orbits, binary star systems and black hole accretion disks and obtain novel insights into these complex systems. Our results deepen our understanding of gravity-induced shape dynamics and provide a useful tool for modelling and predicting the behavior of astronomical objects.

The purpose of this study is to develop an uncertainty-aware self-ensembling model for semi-supervised 3D left atrium segmentation. This approach utilizes a combination of supervised and unsupervised learning techniques, allowing for improved accuracy in segmenting cardiac structures with limited labeled data.
The proposed model consists of two main components: a supervised component that uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) to predict labels for each voxel in the input image, and an unsupervised component that uses k-means clustering to group similar voxels together based on their intensity values. These groups are then used as additional features in the supervised CNN to improve its performance.
To account for uncertainty in the predictions made by the supervised CNN, we introduce a novel uncertainty measure that takes into account both the confidence scores output by the CNN and the variance of these scores across different runs of the model. This measure is used to weight the contributions of the supervised and unsupervised components when combining them in the final prediction.
We evaluate our model on a dataset of 100 patients with varying degrees of label availability, and compare it to state-of-the-art methods using metrics such as Dice coefficient and mean squared error. Our results show that our method outperforms previous approaches, particularly in cases where labeled data is scarce.

The paper explores the compatibility properties of synchronously and asynchronously communicating components in a distributed system. It examines the differences between these two types of communication models, including their advantages and disadvantages, and proposes a framework for evaluating the compatibility of different components based on their communication requirements. The framework takes into account factors such as response time, throughput, and reliability, and provides guidelines for selecting compatible components that can work together effectively in a distributed system. The paper also presents some case studies to illustrate the application of the proposed framework and discusses future research directions in this area. Overall, the paper contributes to our understanding of the challenges involved in building scalable and reliable distributed systems by providing practical guidance on how to select and integrate components with different communication requirements.

The study of neural pathways in zebrafish has been a topic of interest for many years due to their similarities with the human brain. In this paper, we present a novel approach to understanding neural pathways in zebrafish using deep learning and high resolution electron microscope data. Our method involves training a deep neural network on a large dataset of electron microscope images to identify and classify neurons and synapses. We then use this network to analyze the connectivity of neurons in the zebrafish brain and identify key neural pathways. Our results show that our approach is highly accurate and provides new insights into the neural circuits of zebrafish. Overall, our study demonstrates the power of deep learning and high resolution electron microscope data in understanding complex biological systems.

Ordered exchange graphs (OEGs) are a novel type of graph data structure that is designed to model complex exchange processes involving multiple agents or entities. In contrast to traditional graphs, OEGs incorporate an ordering of edges that represents the temporal or logical sequence in which exchanges occur. This ordering allows for more accurate and nuanced modeling of real-world exchange processes, such as financial transactions, supply chain management, and social interactions.

In this paper, we introduce the concept of OEGs and provide a comprehensive overview of their properties and applications. We also present several algorithms for efficiently processing and analyzing OEGs, including algorithms for traversal, clustering, and centrality analysis. We demonstrate the effectiveness of these algorithms through a series of case studies and experiments, and show that OEGs can provide valuable insights into complex exchange processes.

Overall, our work on OEGs represents an important step forward in the development of graph-based models for exchange processes. By incorporating an ordering of edges, OEGs enable more accurate and nuanced modeling of real-world exchange processes, and provide a powerful tool for analyzing and optimizing these processes.

The increasing demand for mobile communication has led to the development of cooperative cellular networks, where multiple cells work together to improve network performance. One of the key challenges faced by these networks is rate balancing between uplink and downlink traffic. This paper presents a novel approach to rate balancing that takes into account both the capacity constraints of individual cells and the overall system-level requirements.
The proposed algorithm uses a game theoretic model to optimize the allocation of resources across cells, with the goal of maximizing overall throughput while minimizing congestion. It also incorporates feedback from users on their perceived quality of service, allowing the system to adapt dynamically to changing user needs.
Experimental results show that the proposed algorithm outperforms existing approaches in terms of both throughput and fairness, demonstrating its potential as a practical solution for managing traffic in cooperative cellular networks.

A nonlinear double slit experiment is used to demonstrate interference patterns of light waves. The optical path length is altered by modulation a mirror placed inside the interferometer, allowing the experimenter to observe how changes in phase and amplitude affect the interference pattern. The results show that small variations in the mirrors position can lead to significant modifications on the width and contrast of the diffraction fringes.

The study presents theoretical modeling and experimental data analysis of this phenomenon. It also shows how different optical paths are created when the laser source emits pulses of different intensities and frequencies. This modifies the way patterns interact with each other and allows us to understand the nature of interference at different levels of intensity and frequency.

Moreover, the research highlights some interesting applications of the nonlinear double slit experiment. For example, it could be used to optimize communication systems and quantum computing protocols. Overall, this work contributes significantly to our understanding of interference phenomena and their practical implications.

In this paper, we propose a novel hierarchical self-supervised learning framework for medical image segmentation based on multi-domain data aggregation. Our approach combines a hierarchical encoder network with a self-supervised autoencoder model that utilizes multiple modalities of domain-specific medical images to learn a hierarchical representation of patients' anatomy. The proposed framework leverages the synergies of multiple domains, such as CT, MRI, and ultrasound, to improve segmentation accuracy and reduce overfitting. Moreover, we propose a novel attention mechanism that allows us to aggregate relevant features from multiple modalities to enhance the hierarchical representation of the patient's anatomy.Experimental results show that our method achieved superior performance compared to state-of-the-art approaches on multiple benchmark datasets, highlighting the effectiveness of our multi-domain data aggregation method and the benefits of multi-modal feature representation in medical image segmentation.

The study of rigidity under lower curvature bound is a fundamental problem in differential geometry. In this paper, we investigate the quantitative volume space form rigidity under such bounds. Specifically, we consider the case where the sectional curvatures are bounded above by a constant $K$ and the total volume of the manifold is bounded below by a constant $\text{Vol}(M)$. We prove that if the metric satisfies these conditions, then it must be isometric to one of a finite number of known examples. Our proof relies on techniques from functional analysis and topology, including the use of the Bochner-Weitzenbck theorem and the theory of Morse functions.

The paper "Exploiting Temporality for Semi-Supervised Video Segmentation" presents a novel approach to the problem of video segmentation, with a focus on using temporal information to improve the performance of the semi-supervised process. The method proposed involves a dual learning framework that combines temporal graph analysis with deep learning techniques. The temporal graph represents the dependencies between frames within a video, while the deep learning models enable the extraction of spatially relevant features. Using this approach, the paper demonstrates significant improvements in the accuracy of video segmentation, as compared to prior methods that use only spatial information. Furthermore, the results highlight the potential benefits of using temporal information for video segmentation, particularly in scenarios where supervised learning is limited or unavailable.

This paper presents a new approach to learning conditional random fields (CRFs) via maximum a posteriori (MAP) decoding. We propose a method that allows for the efficient and accurate learning of CRFs by using the expectations of the MAP decoder as the conditional probability estimates. This approach is applicable to a wide range of CRF models and allows for the incorporation of prior knowledge into the learning process. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method through several case studies and compare it to other state-of-the-art learning algorithms for CRFs. Overall, our approach represents a significant advancement in the field of CRF learning and has practical implications in various domains such as natural language processing, image recognition, and bioinformatics.

Brain tumor segmentation is a crucial step in the diagnosis and treatment of brain tumors. In this study, we propose an ensemble of 3D U-Nets for brain tumor segmentation and overall survival prediction using radiomic features. We first extract radiomic features from the segmented tumor regions and use them as input to a support vector machine (SVM) classifier for overall survival prediction. We then use the SVM classifier to train an ensemble of 3D U-Nets for brain tumor segmentation. Our results show that the ensemble of 3D U-Nets outperforms state-of-the-art methods for brain tumor segmentation and overall survival prediction. Our approach has the potential to improve the accuracy of brain tumor diagnosis and treatment.

The Warsaw Stock Exchange (WSE) is a complex system that exhibits dynamic structural and topological phase transitions. This paper presents a phenomenological approach to understanding these transitions, focusing on the interactions between the various components of the WSE, including the market participants, the trading algorithms, and the underlying financial instruments. The paper uses a combination of qualitative and quantitative methods to analyze the behavior of the WSE, including network analysis, time series analysis, and agent-based modeling. The results show that the WSE exhibits a range of phase transitions, including criticality, chaos, and order, depending on the level of market activity and the interactions between the various components. The paper concludes that a better understanding of these phase transitions is crucial for developing effective trading strategies and improving the stability and efficiency of the WSE.

The purpose of this study is to develop a new annotation strategy that uses active learning and attention mechanisms to improve the accuracy and efficiency of 3D medical image segmentation. The active learning approach involves selecting regions in the image that are most uncertain, while the attention mechanism helps focus the model's attention on relevant information by dynamically weighting the input features. Experiments show that our sparse annotation strategy outperforms previous methods and is more computationally efficient than traditional labeled data approaches.

Abstract:
In this paper, we present a novel sparse annotation strategy for 3D medical image segmentation using active learning with attention guidance. Our method utilizes deep neural networks with attention maps to selectively emphasize important information during training. In addition, our annotation strategy uses limited number of expert labeling to only select the most uncertain areas in an image. We evaluate the performance of our network on six publicly available databases for organ atlas creation and segmentation tasks. Results indicate that our method achieves better segmentation results with less amount of annotations compared to other state-of-the-art techniques. Furthermore, we also demonstrate the feasibility of applicating the proposed strategy on clinical domains such as CT, MRI and US.

Active learning is a popular approach to machine learning that involves selecting the most informative samples to label and train a model. In the context of image segmentation, active learning can be used to improve the accuracy of the model by selecting the most challenging regions to label. However, uncertainty estimation is a key component of active learning, as it allows the model to identify the regions that are most uncertain and therefore most likely to benefit from labeling. In this paper, we explore different approaches to uncertainty estimation in the context of image segmentation, including entropy-based methods, variance-based methods, and deep learning-based methods. We evaluate the performance of these methods on several benchmark datasets and show that deep learning-based methods generally outperform the other approaches. We also discuss some of the challenges and limitations of uncertainty estimation in active learning for image segmentation, and suggest some directions for future research.

"Fuzzy Differences-in-Differences" is an academic paper that presents an innovative method for comparing the fuzzy values of two different variables over time. The paper introduces a new approach to calculating differences in the fuzzy values of two variables using fuzzy set theory. The method is used to analyze the fuzzy differences between two variables, such as stock prices, over a given period. The paper shows that fuzzy differences in fuzzy data can be calculated easily using the proposed method, and the results are compared with other existing methods. The proposed method provides useful insights into the differences between fuzzy values of two variables, and it can be applied to various fields, including finance, economics, and engineering. Furthermore, the paper demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method using numerical examples and shows that it outperforms other methods in terms of accuracy and simplicity. Overall, the paper presents a new and important tool for analyzing fuzzy data and can contribute significantly to the development of fuzzy sets theory and applications.

Lidar point clouds are widely used in various applications such as autonomous vehicles, robotics, and 3D reconstruction. However, generating high-quality point clouds requires expensive and time-consuming data collection and processing. In this paper, we propose a novel approach called DSCnet (Deep Sensor Cloning) to replicate lidar point clouds with deep learning. DSCnet learns to clone lidar point clouds by training a deep neural network to predict the point cloud data from a set of input features. The input features include the sensor parameters, the sensor position, and the sensor orientation. We evaluate DSCnet on several benchmark datasets and show that it can generate high-quality point clouds with low computational cost. Our approach has the potential to revolutionize the field of lidar point cloud generation and enable real-time and cost-effective applications.

In this paper, we present a novel 3D deep learning architecture called 3D RoI-aware U-Net to accurately segment colorectal tumors in endoscopic images. The proposed approach leverages Region of Interest (RoI) detection to focus attention on regions of interest related to cancerous tissue during training, improving the network's ability to accurately segment high-variability colorectal tumors. We also utilize transfer learning by utilizing pre-trained VGG16 models as feature extractors for our own model to reduce computation time and improve performance. Our experimental results indicate that our proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of segmentation accuracy with significantly faster runtime. Therefore, our method can provide doctors and patients with more reliable diagnosis information about colorectal tumors at lower costs and speeds.

The abstract for the academic paper titled "CUSUM Filter for Brain Segmentation on DSC Perfusion MR Head Scans with Abnormal Brain Anatomy" would be:

Background: Dynamic Susceptibility Contrast (DSC) magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a powerful tool for detecting and quantifying brain perfusion abnormalities. However, the accuracy of DSC perfusion MRI can be affected by abnormal brain anatomy, such as tumors or vascular malformations. In this study, we propose a novel method for brain segmentation on DSC perfusion MR head scans with abnormal brain anatomy using a CUSUM filter.

Methods: We applied a CUSUM filter to the DSC perfusion MR images of 20 patients with abnormal brain anatomy. The CUSUM filter was used to identify regions of interest (ROIs) in the DSC perfusion images, and the ROIs were then segmented using a thresholding method. The segmented ROIs were compared with manual segmentations performed by expert radiologists to evaluate the accuracy of the proposed method.

Results: The proposed method achieved an accuracy of 95% in segmenting ROIs in the DSC perfusion images. The segmented ROIs were also found to be highly correlated with the manual segmentations performed by expert radiologists.

Conclusion: The proposed method using a CUSUM filter for brain segmentation on DSC perfusion MR head scans with abnormal brain anatomy is a promising tool for accurately detecting and quantifying brain perfusion abnormalities in patients with abnormal brain anatomy. Further studies are needed to validate the proposed method in a larger cohort of patients.

This paper presents a new measure of economic complexity, based on the idea that the complexity of an economy can be captured by the number of distinct industries it contains. We argue that this measure is simple to compute, yet captures an important aspect of economic diversity and differentiation. We provide evidence from a variety of sources, including industry classification systems and firm-level data, that our measure is robust and captures important features of economic complexity. We also discuss some of the limitations of our measure and suggest directions for future research. Overall, our paper provides a useful tool for understanding the complexity of economies and for comparing the complexity of different regions and time periods.

The field of computer vision has seen significant advancements in recent years, with deep learning techniques such as convolutional neural networks (CNNs) achieving state-of-the-art performance on various tasks. However, these models often require large amounts of labeled data to achieve high accuracy, which can be a significant barrier to entry for many applications. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to address this challenge by leveraging the importance of different features for segmentation across domains. Specifically, we introduce a method for continual learning that updates the model's weights based on the importance of each feature for the current task, rather than simply updating the entire model. This allows the model to adapt to new domains and tasks more efficiently, while still maintaining high accuracy on previously seen data. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark datasets, and show that it outperforms traditional continual learning methods in many cases. Our work has important implications for the development of more efficient and adaptable computer vision systems.

In this study, we investigate the convergence rates of distributed Nesterov-like gradient methods on random networks. We analyze two popular variants: the centralized Nesterov gradient method and its decentralized version. Our results show that under certain regularity assumptions on the distribution of the network's edges and vertex degrees, both methods converge with linear speed. Specifically, we prove a convergence rate of O(1) for the two algorithms in terms of the number of iterations required to achieve accurate solutions. This result is especially important in large-scale optimization problems where practical convergence times can be prohibitively long for other standard optimization techniques. Furthermore, our analysis provides useful insights into the properties that characterize efficient gradients methods in random network settings. Overall, our work contributes to understanding the fundamental convergence mechanisms of distributed gradient methods applied to optimization over networked data structures.

The single chain slip-spring model is a widely used method for simulating the rheological behavior of entangled polymers. However, the traditional implementation of this model is computationally expensive and time-consuming, making it difficult to simulate large-scale systems in real-time. In this paper, we propose a new approach to the single chain slip-spring model that utilizes the power of graphics processing units (GPUs) to significantly reduce the computational cost of simulations. Our method involves dividing the simulation domain into smaller subdomains and applying the slip-spring model to each subdomain independently on a GPU. This approach allows us to simulate large-scale systems in real-time, making it possible to study the behavior of entangled polymers under a wide range of conditions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method by comparing the results of our simulations with those of traditional slip-spring models and experimental data. Our results show that our method provides accurate and reliable simulations of entangled polymers, and that it is significantly faster and more efficient than traditional methods.

Image segmentation is a crucial task in computer vision and has numerous applications in various fields. Traditional image segmentation methods rely on manual thresholding or use a single threshold for the entire image. However, these methods often fail to capture the complexities in the image and result in poor segmentation. In this paper, we propose a novel approach for image segmentation using learning automata. Our approach utilizes multiple thresholds for image segmentation, where each threshold is learned based on the image's characteristics. We use a learning automaton to learn the optimal thresholds for each image, which results in improved segmentation accuracy. Our approach is tested on various benchmark datasets, and the results show that our method outperforms traditional methods in terms of segmentation accuracy.

This paper investigates the relationship between financial market structure and the real economy, specifically comparing clustering methods. The study uses data from various countries to analyze the impact of different market structures on economic growth and development. The results show that there is a positive correlation between openness and efficiency in financial markets and GDP per capita. Additionally, the study finds that the level of competition within the banking sector has a significant effect on overall economic performance. These findings suggest that policymakers should focus on promoting greater competition and opening up financial markets in order to foster economic growth and development.

Explicit evidence systems (EES) are a type of knowledge representation that use explicit, structured representations to represent and reason about knowledge. In this paper, we explore the role of common knowledge in EESs, specifically focusing on how it can be used to improve reasoning and decision-making processes. We propose a framework for incorporating common knowledge into EESs, which involves identifying relevant facts and concepts, representing them using formal logic, and integrating them into existing knowledge structures. We also discuss some potential challenges and limitations associated with this approach, including issues related to scalability and complexity. Overall, our work provides valuable insights into the benefits and challenges of incorporating common knowledge into EESs, and offers practical guidance for researchers and practitioners working in this area.

The abstract for the academic paper titled "Sem-GAN: Semantically-Consistent Image-to-Image Translation" is as follows:

Image-to-image translation is a challenging task in computer vision and machine learning, which requires learning a mapping from a source image to a target image while preserving the semantic meaning of the image. This requires not only the ability to translate the visual contents but also the understanding of the underlying semantic structure of the images. In this paper, we present a novel approach called Sem-GAN, which addresses the problem of semantically-consistent image-to-image translation. Sem-GAN employs a novel multi-task learning framework, where the generator is trained to generate target images that are not only realistic but also semantically consistent with the source image. We use a combination of traditional supervised learning tasks and adversarial learning to achieve this. We evaluate Sem-GAN on multiple benchmark datasets and show that it achieves state-of-the-art performance while preserving the semantic consistency of the generated images.

The use of generative adversarial networks (GANs) has revolutionized image generation and manipulation. However, GANs often suffer from inconsistent perceptions across different scales or resolutions. In this study, we propose a novel method to enforce perceptual consistency in GAN-generated images using the normalized Laplacian pyramid distance. Our approach involves training two separate GAN models: one for generating high-resolution images and another for generating low-resolution versions of these images. We then calculate the normalized Laplacian pyramid distance between the generated high-resolution and low-resolution images to measure their perceptual consistency. By minimizing this distance during training, our model learns to generate images that are consistent across different scales. Our experiments demonstrate significant improvements in perceptual consistency compared to previous methods, making our approach suitable for applications such as medical imaging and video compression.

The abstract for the academic paper titled "Polarization Properties of A Multi-Moded Concentrator" would likely describe the study's focus on the polarization properties of a multi-mode concentrator. The concentrator is a device used to combine multiple optical signals into a single signal for transmission over a fiber optic cable. The study would likely explore the effects of polarization on the performance of the concentrator, including its ability to transmit signals over long distances and its resistance to noise and interference. The abstract would also summarize the methods used in the study, such as experimental setups and theoretical models, and the results obtained, including any notable findings or conclusions. Overall, the abstract would provide a brief overview of the study's objectives, methods, and key findings, highlighting the importance of polarization properties in the design and operation of multi-mode concentrators.

The fourth-order gradient plasticity model is a widely used mathematical tool in materials science and engineering to predict deformation behavior under different loading conditions. However, its accuracy depends on several factors such as material properties, boundary conditions, and loading history. In this study, we present a localization analysis of the energy-based fourth-order gradient plasticity model using finite element methods. Our approach involves solving the nonlinear differential equations governing the evolution of the strain field and the internal state variables at each spatial location. We also develop a new algorithm that allows us to efficiently compute the localized stresses and strains at any point within the domain. Our results show that our method provides accurate predictions of the localized stresses and strains, even in complex geometries with multiple loading paths. Furthermore, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach by comparing it with experimental data from various materials systems. Overall, our work contributes to the development of more reliable and efficient tools for predicting the mechanical behavior of materials under different loading conditions.

This paper presents a novel approach to image segmentation that leverages diversity in both the training data and model architecture. We first introduce a new dataset, called Multi-Domain ImageNet (MDI), which consists of images from multiple domains, captured under different lighting conditions, angles, and scales. We then propose an ensemble learning framework that combines multiple deep neural networks trained on subsets of MDI with diverse architectures, regularization techniques, and loss functions. Our experiments show that this approach significantly improves the performance of image segmentation models on various benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results in some cases. Furthermore, we analyze the contributions of each component of our framework and demonstrate its effectiveness in handling complex scenes with high levels of visual variability. Overall, our work highlights the importance of exploring and exploiting diversity in computer vision tasks and provides a valuable resource for researchers and practitioners interested in improving the robustness and generalizability of image segmentation models.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach for 3D object segmentation with exponential logarithmic loss (ELL) for highly unbalanced object sizes. The proposed method is designed to address the challenges of segmenting objects with varying sizes and densities, which are common in many real-world applications. We use a combination of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and ELL to improve the accuracy and robustness of the segmentation task. Our experiments show that the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets, including the COCO-Text and the MPII Human Pose datasets. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on real-world applications, such as autonomous driving and medical imaging. Overall, our work represents a significant advancement in the field of 3D object segmentation, and has important implications for a wide range of applications in computer vision and robotics.

Psi-Net is a novel deep learning architecture designed specifically for medical image segmentation tasks. It utilizes shape and boundary awareness to improve performance on complex images with varying shapes, sizes, and boundaries. The model consists of multiple subnetworks that are trained simultaneously to perform different segmentation tasks, such as tumor detection and lesion classification. These subnetworks share common features and learn from each other through a joint training process. Additionally, Psi-Net incorporates attention mechanisms to focus on important regions in the input image and adaptively adjust the level of detail based on the task at hand. Overall, Psi-Net demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets and offers a flexible framework for customizing the model to specific clinical needs.

The paper "On p-adic differential equations with separation of variables" explores the study of p-adic differential equations with the assumption of separation of variables. The authors introduce the concept of p-adic differential equations and provide a brief overview of the existing literature on the subject. They then proceed to develop a new approach to solving p-adic differential equations using separation of variables. The paper presents several examples of p-adic differential equations and their solutions using the new approach. The authors also discuss the limitations of the separation of variables method and suggest future research directions. Overall, the paper provides a valuable contribution to the field of p-adic differential equations and offers new insights into the study of these equations.

The abstract for the academic paper titled "Sigma Point Belief Propagation" is as follows:

Title: Sigma Point Belief Propagation

Author: John Doe

Abstract: This paper presents a new approach to belief propagation in Bayesian networks, based on the sigma point method. The sigma point method is a technique used in stochastic process control to estimate the state of the process, and it can be extended to belief propagation in Bayesian networks by using sigma points to represent the state of the network.

The proposed approach uses sigma points to initialize the belief distribution and then iteratively updates the belief distribution using Bayesian rule and the sigma point method. The paper also presents a new algorithm for computing the probability of the next sigma point using Bayesian update rule and the sigma point method.

The proposed approach is shown to be effective in estimating the posterior probability of the network parameters in a Bayesian model, as well as in computing the likelihood of the network parameters given new data. The paper concludes with a comparison with existing belief propagation methods, and the results show that the proposed method is computationally efficient and accurate.

The objective of this study is to develop efficient and practical methods for registering dense image volumes, such as magnetic resonance images (MRIs) or computed tomography (CT) scans. We focus on developing a graph-cut optimizer that can handle deformable registration, i.e., registration with non-rigid transformations between the image volumes. Our graph-cut optimizer is an extension of the existing methods for rigid registration, which require iterative optimization to minimize the cost function that describes the difference between the image volumes. Our optimizer is fast, i.e., it can handle large image volumes efficiently, and produces good results in practice. We evaluate our optimizer on various benchmark datasets, including brain MRIs and CT scans, and compare it with existing methods for rigid registration and deformable registration. Our results demonstrate that our optimizer produces accurate registration for dense deformable image volumes, while being significantly faster than existing methods.

The paper presents a novel approach to forward and backward propagation of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for pixelwise classification. The proposed method utilizes a combination of forward and backward propagation to improve the efficiency of the training process. The forward propagation is used to compute the output of the network, while the backward propagation is used to update the weights of the network. The paper demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method through experiments on various datasets, including the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets. The results show that the proposed method achieves significant improvements in training time and accuracy compared to traditional methods.

In this paper, we present a novel approach to continual learning that is driven by domain importance. The proposed method enables models trained on multiple domains to continuously learn from new data while prioritizing tasks based on their relative importance across all domains. Specifically, our algorithm calculates an import score for each task in each domain and uses it to guide updates to the model's parameters during training. This allows us to balance contributions from different tasks and domains, making our model more robust and effective than those trained only in individual domains or without considering task importance. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method through several experiments involving multisource image segmentation tasks and validate its performance using metrics such as accuracy, transferability, and adaptability. Our results show that our importance-driven continual learning technique outperforms state-of-the-art methods on these metrics and demonstrates the potential for AI systems to effectively engage with multiple sources of information at once.

Urban design is becoming an increasingly complex field, influenced by factors such as population growth, transportation needs, and environmental concerns. One way to address some of these challenges is through multi-objective optimization (MOO), where multiple objectives are simultaneously optimized towards a set of conflicting constraints. This approach has been applied successfully to various areas of engineering, but there is limited research on its use in urban design problems due to the complexity involved. In this paper, we present a multimethodological study of MOO techniques in an urban design context. We use two representative benchmark problems - one modeling building layout and another city planning - both involving spatially fragmented mesh structures that require distributed network analysis. Our results show that using multi-objectiv

The aim of this paper is to introduce a novel artificial neural network, UI-Net, designed for iterative image segmentation. The proposed model is based on the idea of interactive learning, where the user provides feedback on the segmentation performance, and the model updates itself accordingly.
The UI-Net consists of multiple artificial neural network layers, each of which is designed to learn a specific feature from the input image. The network is initially initialized with a rough segmentation, and the user then provides feedback on areas where the segmentation is incorrect. The UI-Net then refines its segmentation based on this feedback and continues to learn until the user is satisfied with the result.
The proposed model is designed to be flexible and adaptive, allowing users to fine-tune the segmentation based on their specific needs. The model can also be trained on different datasets and can be modified to suit different image segmentation tasks.
In this paper, we demonstrate the effectiveness of the UI-Net through a series of experiments, including the task of brain segmentation. Our results show that the UI-Net outperforms existing segmentation models and provides a more accurate and efficient solution for interactive image segmentation.

In this paper, we explore the local quantum uncertainty in two-qubit separable states. We examine the concept of separability and show that it affects the quantifiable uncertainty in the states of two qubits. We conduct a case study on entangled states, where we demonstrate that the uncertainty in separable entangled states is less than that in non-separable entangled states. We also consider various metrics for measuring uncertainty, such as linear entropy and von Neumann entropy, and show how they are related to the local separability of states. Our study has important implications for quantum systems and is relevant to many fields, including cryptography, quantum computing, and quantum information processing.

The field of dermatology has seen a significant increase in the use of artificial intelligence (AI) to aid in skin lesion image segmentation and classification. However, most existing frameworks require extensive training data and computational resources, making them impractical for clinical settings. In this study, we propose a self-learning AI framework that can automatically learn from limited training data and adapt to new images without requiring additional manual labeling or retraining. Our approach utilizes transfer learning techniques to leverage pre-trained models on related tasks such as object detection and semantic segmentation. We evaluate our framework on a dataset of skin lesions and demonstrate its ability to accurately segment and classify lesions with comparable performance to state-of-the-art methods. Our results suggest that our self-learning AI framework could be a valuable tool for clinicians and researchers seeking an efficient and cost-effective solution for skin lesion analysis.

Source-free domain adaptation for image segmentation is a challenging problem in computer vision. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to address this problem by leveraging the power of deep learning. Specifically, we propose a deep neural network architecture that can learn to adapt to new image domains without any prior knowledge of the source domain. Our approach is based on the idea of learning a mapping function that maps the features of the source domain to the features of the target domain. We train this mapping function using a large amount of data from the target domain, and then use it to adapt the segmentation model to the target domain. Our experiments show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets.

Submodular optimization is a powerful technique used to solve complex combinatorial problems in various fields, including machine learning and operations research. However, finding optimal solutions using submodular optimization can be challenging due to its non-convex nature and high computational complexity. In this paper, we propose reflection methods that enable efficient and effective submodular optimization by leveraging the structure of the objective function and problem constraints. Our approach involves constructing surrogate models based on convex relaxations or concave approximations of the original submodular objective function, which allows us to efficiently find near-optimal solutions through iterative refinements. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our methodology through several case studies, including clustering and facility location problems, where we show significant improvements over state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of both solution quality and computational efficiency. Overall, our work provides valuable insights into the design of user-friendly submodular optimization techniques that can be applied to a wide range of real-world problems.

Cluster initialization is a vital step in unsupervised learning, and it is very important to identify dense and separated clusters in the data. A deep learning-based object detection method can be used to efficiently initialize clusters. In this paper, we present a deep learning-based object detection method that uses convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to identify and separate clusters. We first define the cluster initialization problem as an object detection task, where each object represents a cluster. We train a CNN-based object detector on a dataset of densely clustered data, using the focal loss function to improve the performance in cases of imbalance between positive and negative samples. We use the trained object detector to initialize the clusters by setting the clusters' centers as the detected objects' centers. We compare our method with other cluster initialization methods on several datasets and show that our method performs better in terms of cluster separation and accuracy. Our method is efficient and can be used in real-time applications, making it a useful tool for unsupervised learning.

Deep geodesic learning is a novel approach to segmentation and anatomical landmarking that leverages the advantages of both deep learning and geometric methods. This technique utilizes a combination of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and distance-preserving geometry to model complex shapes and structures in medical images. The proposed method reduces overfitting, preserves topological properties, and enables more accurate label transfer across similar subjects or scans. Our experiments demonstrate effective use of this approach on segmentation tasks in various imaging modalities such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomography (CT). Furthermore, we showcase its applicability for automatic identification of key anatomic features such as tumor boundaries, ventricles, hippocampi and basal ganglia. Overall, deep geodesic learning offers promising results for achieving state-of-the-art performance while addressing major challenges in medical image processing.

Frame reference, a coordinate transformation between reference frames in physics, is a crucial tool for understanding and analyzing complex systems. In this paper, we propose a new mathematical framework for describing frame reference as a 4-invariants, i.e., four sets of equations that describe the transformation from one reference frame to another.

The four-invariant approach has several advantages. Firstly, it provides a compact and elegant representation of the transformation, allowing for more efficient computations and easier numerical integration. Secondly, it highlights the algebraic relationships between the various components of the frame reference transformation, making it easier to understand and interpret the results.

We also demonstrate the power of the four-invariant approach through several examples, including the transformation between Cartesian and spherical Coordinates. We show that the approach is flexible enough to handle non-orthogonal frames as well, and that it can be easily extended to higher dimensions.

Overall, this paper provides a valuable contribution to the field of physics by introducing a new mathematical framework for describing frame reference as a 4-invariants. The approach is simple, elegant, and powerful, and has the potential to greatly improve the efficiency and accuracy of numerical simulations and computations in physics.

This paper presents a new approach to analyzing timed systems, based on tree automata theory. We introduce a novel formalism called Timed Tree Automata (TTA) that can model and verify time-dependent behaviors of concurrent systems. TTA extends traditional deterministic finite state machines with clocks and timing constraints. It allows us to capture temporal dependencies between events in a system, enabling precise analysis of its behavior under various conditions.

The main contributions of this work are as follows: (1) we introduce the concept of Time Pattern Languages defined over TTAs, which provide a powerful tool to express time-varying patterns in system behavior; (2) we develop algorithms for computing reachability, acceptance, and other important properties of TTAs, including a decidable algorithm for determining whether a language is recognized by an infinite branch automaton of a given TTA; (3) we apply our results to verify correctness of timed communication protocols and establish tradeoffs among different performance metrics such as latency, jitter, and packet loss.

We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach using several case studies, and show that it provides more accurate and efficient analysis than existing techniques. Our results have potential applications in various domains, from computer science and engineering to biological and social sciences, where the nature of time plays a crucial role in modeling complex phenomena.

The paper investigates the properties of free $\omega$-continuous and regular ordered algebras. We first prove that every free $\omega$-continuous ordered algebra is isomorphic to the free $\omega$-continuous ordered algebra on a countable dense subset of the real line.
